column2: Albion bred warhorses are hardy, fast and sure-footed. However, only wealthy warriors can afford to ride on to battle.
The chariots built in Albion might look crude to more civilized folk, but they are well constructed and suprisingly dangerous on the field.
Albion bred warhorses are hardy, fast and sure-footed. However, only wealthy warriors can afford to ride on to battle.

Albion bred warhorses are hardy, fast and sure-footed. However, only wealthy warriors can afford to ride on to battle.
The only giant raven who has ever been spotted in the skies of Albion serves Morrigan as her loyal companion, allowing her to take to the skies whenever she desires to do so.
Morrigan is rarely ever seen without this staff which looks like a mere branch of a random tree. But those who know what to look for easily notice that it brims with magical power.
The fine nose of this animal detects hidden enemies and alarms his master if unseen foes are near.
This frenzied warrior will fight the enemies of Albion wherever he encounters them.
Maybe this is a messanger of Morrigan's Flock, maybe he is just a tame Raven. Be it as it may, this bird faithfully accompanies its master, always on the hunt for glittering objects.
Truthsayers who are too old or fragile to continue serving on the battlefield or casting exhausting spells will often serve as advisors to chieftains and warleaders.
Chieftains are figures of authority among the tribes. Not all of them fight on the battlefield, but even those who do not will help the war effort by maintaining order on the battlefield.
Not many warriors of Albion are skilled or lucky enough to make it to old age. Those who do inspire the younger men of their tribe with stories of valor.
Sacking and looting settlements is sometimes required for the survival of the tribe. And some tribesmen are better at it than others.
Women of Albion may choose to take up arms, just like men. Those who do not are expected to learn a craft such as healing or hunting.
Truthsayers will sometimes use Fenbeasts as bodyguards. Their inability to betray their masters and intimidating appearance make them well suited for this task.
Members of the Hearthguard serve as bodyguards for important chiefs, warleaders and druids.
A Truthsayer who is still learning his craft. He is already able to manipulate the winds of magic to his favour though.
This hardened warrior has seen many battles. His calm, stalwart presence inspires the warriors of the army and his knowledge in warfare is very benefitial.
This grizzly banner is a reminder of the more savage aspects of the culture of Albion. It is decorated with skulls and bones of slain foes, both beast and human alike.
Not many travel alone through the dangerous wilds of Albion. Those who do are either foolhardy or exceptionally skilled - sometimes both at the same time.
Those who fight under the Banner of the Earth goddess benefit from her protection.
Only in times of war would hunters borther to carry a banner.
One of the best guarded secret of the Truthsayers is the art of forging a Staff of Light. These weapons allow the Truthsayers who wield them to hinder the magic of their opponents.
A magic talisman with the sign of the Triskele carved into it. It is given to accomplished Truthsayers and its magic will protect them from harm.
It is said that this hammer has been imbued with the strength of Bologs, greatest of Albion's giants. It is certainly heavy enough to require giant strength to be swung around by its user.
Blessed by Lugh, the sun god, this shield burns arrows and foes alike if they are getting too close to it.
A heavy spear designed to hunt the big, mutated beasts of Albion's swamps. It pierces the thickest hide just as well as a Fimir's armour.

It is said that this weapon was taken from a Fimir near the Citadel of Lead. It is turning its wielder into an excellent killer, however there is a cost to be paid. None of its wielders seem to get very old.
The best armour Albion can produce, favoured by its nobility and everyone else who can afford it.
A helmet made for leaders of armies, enchanted to enhance their voice and keep their mind calm.
The Earthmother blesses those who fight in her name with her powers.
Strange signs are carved into this oddly shaped talisman. If a Dark Emissary could get his hands on it, he would recognize a fragment of his master's powers sealed within.

An ancient item left behind by the mysterious Old Ones. The Truthsayer holding it might tap into its power when casting spells and even though he doesn't understand it, he can activate its magical effect.
A Staff of Light modified by a Dark Emissary. Even though it pains the Truthsayer to do so, he can use the enemies weapons if he must, although the risk might not be worth the power it holds.
The shard of an old, collapsed Ogham Stone. It still holds a fraction of its former power.
This small wooden figurine has been enchanted to aid hunters in their dangerous expeditions.

Accomplished Albion Warriors often take trophies from worthy foes and have Truthsayers preserve them in secret rites. They are then worn into battle and supposed to strengthen the warrior with the power of their slain enemy.
A magic banner emblazoned with the sign of the Triskele. It is given to accomplished Truthsayers and its magic will protect them from harm.
A magic banner emblazoned with the sign of the Triskele. It is given to accomplished Truthsayers and its magic will protect them from harm.
When Dural Durak casts spells, this staff of his own creation twists the Winds of Magic in a way that disturbs the efforts of enemy casters.
One of the last functioning artifacts of the Old Ones remaining in the hands of the tribes of Albion, this amulet can save the life of its wearer once per battle with a surge of magical energy.
Albion bred warhorses are hardy, fast and sure-footed. However, only wealthy warriors can afford to ride on to battle.
The chariots built in Albion might look crude to more civilized folk, but they are well constructed and suprisingly dangerous on the field.
